metadata.title: Moebius Syndrome  Communication Disorders
synonyms: moebius congenital oculofacial paralysis: communication disorders
congenital ophthalmoplegia and facial paresis: communication disorders
congenital oculofacial paralysis, moebius: communication disorders
paresis, congenital ophthalmoplegia and facial: communication disorders
paralysis, moebius congenital oculofacial: communication disorders
anatomical location body part affected: 6th and 7th cranial nerves; the eyes, the face
description: Moebius syndrome is a rare congenital disorder characterized by paralysis of the 6th (abducens) and 7th (facial) cranial nerves.(1) Patients with Moebius syndrome are unable to move the eyes laterally or move the muscles of the face to produce facial expressions, including smiling.(1) In some cases of Moebius syndrome, additional cranial nerves are involved, resulting in additional physical abnormalities(1)
In 2007, the Moebius Syndrome Foundation estimated that there were 2,000 individuals worldwide affected by Moebius syndrome(2)

ICD-10 codes.Q87.0: congenital malformation syndromes predominantly affecting facial appearance (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

Motor Speech G-code set.G8999: Motor speech functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Motor Speech G-code set.G9186: Motor speech functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Motor Speech G-code set.G9158: Motor speech functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/ end of reporting on limitation

Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9174: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9175: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9176: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The main symptoms that are consistent among all patients with Moebius syndrome are an inability to move the eyes laterally and to move the muscles of the face.(1) Because of the complete or partial paralysis of the facial nerve, patients with Moebius syndrome appear to have a mask-like  facial expression.(1) Additional possible signs and symptoms include
weakness of the muscles that control eyelid movement; inability to completely close the eyelids during sleep(1)
hypoglossia (short, underdeveloped tongue; occurs in cases in which the 12th [hypoglossal] cranial nerve is affected)(1,3)

dysphagia; sucking problems in infants; worse in patients with 9th (glossopharyngeal) cranial nerve involvement(1) –Infants with Moebius syndrome are unable to breastfeed or suck from a regular bottle nipple and must be fed with a specialized device such as Medela’s SpecialNeeds Feeder (formerly called the Haberman Feeder)(1) –For detailed information on dysphagia in Moebius syndrome, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Moebius Syndrome ; Topic ID Number: T709247
missing or misaligned teeth (both primary and permanent)(1,3)
thoracic abnormalities(1) –Scoliosis(1) –Brachial muscle deformity(2) –Pectoral hypoplasia(1) –Absence of the pectoral muscle(1,2)
limb deformities(1) –Webbed, absent, short, or deformed fingers(1) –Club foot(1,2) –Flat foot(1)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) must be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communicative functioning as well as during assessment and when developing treatment goals. Communication needs of the patient should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting

Family members/caregivers should be involved in both assessment and treatment of pediatric patients as they have a unique perspective and can provide information on the child that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures

causes: the etiology of moebius syndrom: One hypothesis is that Moebius syndrome results from disruption of blood flow to the brainstem in utero(1)–Disruption of blood flow to a developing fetus can be caused by drugs or environmental insults(1)–If an intrauterine injury is causative, it would likely occur in 4–7 weeks’ gestation as this is the critical period for theembryonic development of the 6th and 7th cranial nerves(1,2)–In other studies researchers have found that such drugs as misoprostol (which is sometimes taken in early pregnancyto induce miscarriage; however, it is an unreliable abortifacient drug and these pregnancies usually continue to term),benzodiazepines (a class of drugs that act as central nervous system depressants), and cocaine could all cause this type ofblood flow disruption(1)

Abnormalities in several chromosomes (3, 10, and 13) have been proposed as possibly causative with possible modes ofinheritance including X-linked  recessive, autosomal dominant, and autosomal recessive(1,3)–Approximately 2% of cases of Moebius syndrome seem to have a genetic basis; all others appear to be sporadic(2)
pathogenesis: Moebius syndrome is present at birth and is nonprogressive(1,2,3)
Outward symptoms result from damage to the 6th and 7thcranial nerves(1)
risk factors: Use of misoprostol, benzodiazepines, or cocaine by the mother during pregnancy(1,3)

overall contraindications precautions: For children with Moebius syndrome, development of an individualized family service plan (IFSP) or individual education plan (IEP) in collaboration with the parents/guardians and early intervention/school personnel is essential to address communication and swallowing problems in the home and school environment
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) must be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communicative functioning as well as during assessment and when developing treatment goals. Communication needs of the patient should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting

Family members/caregivers should be involved in both assessment and treatment of pediatric patients as they have a unique perspective and can provide information on the child that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when the patient’s physician confirmed the diagnosis of Moebius syndrome -Moebius syndrome is classified and diagnosed based on clinical findings(1) -In 2007 at the biannual Moebius Syndrome Foundation conference, a group of clinicians and researchers defined the minimal diagnostic criteria for classic Moebius syndrome as “congenital, uni- or bilateral, nonprogressive facial weakness and limited abduction of the eye(s)”(14) -In a prospective, observational study conducted in the United States with 112 participants (ages 6 months to 62 years) in whom Moebius syndrome previously had been diagnosed by a physician, researchers found that 21/112 of the participants did not meet the abovementioned minimum diagnostic criteria for Moebius syndrome.(14) Genetic testing was performed on all of the participants in the study, and many of those individuals not meeting the minimum diagnostic criteria for Moebius syndrome were found to have genetic abnormalities consistent with other rare disorders (e.g., congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles [CFEOM]). The authors of this study recommended that “full vertical motility” of the eye be added as part of the above minimum diagnostic criteria for Moebius syndrome so that the condition will be more accurately diagnosed and individuals receive the proper information regarding treatment, prognosis, and genetic counseling from their physicians(14)  -There are four recognized categories of Moebius syndromecharacterized by small or absent brainstem nuclei that control the cranial nerves(2,4)marked by the loss and weakening of neurons in the facial peripheral nerve(2,4)characterized by the loss and degeneration of neurons and other brain cells, microscopic areas of damage, and hardened tissue in the brainstem nuclei(2,4)marked by muscular symptoms despite a lack of lesions in the cranial nerve(s)(2,4) -The acronym “CLUFT” is used to classify and grade the severity of Moebius syndrome according to which parts of the body are involved(1) -Cranial nerve(1) -Lower limb(1) -Upper limb(1) -Face(1) -Thorax(1) -Document communication history, including speech and language milestones as well as any motor and developmental delays(3,4)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of Moebius syndrome varies from patient to patient according to the individual’s specific symptoms(1) There is no specific course of treatment for individuals with Moebius syndrome(1) Infants with Moebius syndrome will require either a feeding tube or a specialized adaptive feeding device to maintain nutritional needs(1) Breast milk can be expressed and fed to the infant through the selected device(1) Surgery can be effective to correct crossed eyes, improve limb function, or fix jaw deformities(1) Plastic reconstructive surgery can be beneficial for some individuals with Moebius syndrome; nerve and muscle transfers to the corners of the mouth have been documented to provide a limited ability to smile(1) The “smile surgery” involves taking a portion of the gracilis muscle in the thigh along with its attached blood supply and transplanting it to the face; the motor nerve of the masseter muscle (5th [trigeminal] cranial nerve) is used to innervate the gracilis muscle(1) In a study conducted in Canada of 12 children (mean age 10.2 years) with Moebius syndrome who underwent this surgery, researchers found that speech intelligibility in conversationlevel speech improved significantly, especially with the sounds /p/, /b/, /m/, /w/, /sh/, /f/, and /v/(5) Due to the inability to fully close the eyelid (and therefore difficulty blinking and closing the eye), eye irritation, corneal dryness, and corneal erosion can occur(1) Artificial tears can improve the moisture of the eye(1) An ophthalmologist might stitch small gold weights into the upper eyelid to improve closure(1) Use of colored contact lenses, sunglasses, and brimmed hats is recommended to prevent damage from strong sunlight(1)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Document the results of any diagnostic tests completed, including previous speech/ language assessments
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech-language,  occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there any situations that seem to improve or reduce the patient’s speech intelligibility? Are there any specific food textures that facilitate or impair oral intake of food?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms; see Presenting signs/symptoms , above
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Sleep disturbances can occur due to inability to close the eyes as well as problems from drooling or aspiration(1,3)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., fine motor problems, dry eyes, cough)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document respiratory status -Individuals with Moebius syndrome can have involvement of any of the 12 cranial nerves and sometimes require a permanent tracheostomy tube(1,2)Many individuals with Moebius syndrome are psychologically well-adjusted;  however, there is an increased risk of psychosocial, behavioral, and social problems(1,6,7) -Because a patient with Moebius syndrome does not have the ability to initiate facial movement, peers may believe that the person feels no emotions, which can lead to social isolation(1) -Onlookers sometimes interpret the blank, mask-like  look on the face of an individual with Moebius syndrome as disinterested, bored, rude, or as an indication of low intelligence or intellectual disability(1) -Adolescence is usually the most difficult time for individuals with Moebius syndrome due to the importance of “fitting in” and looking like peers during this time(1,7,16) -Bullying is a common experience for teenagers with Moebius syndrome(16) -Individuals with Moebius syndrome often have lower levels of social competence than typically developing peers due to the reduced opportunities for social interaction(6) -Despite their inability to produce facial expressions, patients with Moebius syndrome do not have difficulty interpreting the facial expressions of others(1) -Lack of facial expression in an infant with Moebius syndrome can hinder parental attachment; counseling for parents of an infant with Moebius syndrome can help prevent attachment problems(1) -Parents of children with Moebius syndrome can experience significantly more stress than parents of typically developing children; there is an increased risk of parental stress if the child has depression, anxiety, or aggressive behaviors(7) -Refer the patient and/or parent(s)/family members to social services and/or a mental health professional for support as appropriate(7) -In a study conducted in the United States of 18 adults with Moebius syndrome, researchers found that family support, humor, faith, a sense of self, special skills, determination, and connecting with other patients with Moebius syndrome were significant sources of strength and resiliency(1,8)Document hearing abilities as well as need for/use of hearing aid(s) -Individuals with Moebius syndrome are at increased risk for hearing loss(1,3) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Note history of any craniofacial or communication disorder(s)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient/caregiver about other problems, including hearing loss, strabismus, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), hypotonia, cleft palate, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders(1,3,9,10) Lack of adequate eye protection in childhood is thought to result in the early development of cataracts in some adults with Moebius syndrome(1)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient/caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the speech or swallowing impairment interfere with progress in school or ability to function at home or in a work setting? If age-appropriate, does the patient socialize with peers? Does patient attend daycare or school? Does patient work? Does patient currently receive speech-language services? If so, are they home, school, or clinic based?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Document if and what type of adaptive equipment the patient is using, such as wheelchairs, hearing aids, or glasses -Determine the effect of the patient’s speech and/or swallowing/feeding deficits on participation in home, school, social, and occupational activities
social and occupational history.living environment: Document information about the patient’s living environment (e.g., stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note body mass index (BMI); individuals with Moebius syndrome are at increased risk of malnutrition due to feeding problems(1)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document the use of augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) systems. For individuals with Moebius syndrome who have severely impaired intelligibility of speech, it might be appropriate to assess ability to utilize AAC to improve functional communication. For detailed information regarding the use of AAC for communication, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)Assess articulation skills with formal and informal measures -Due to facial paralysis and weak lip closure as well as possible limitations in tongue mobility and strength, individuals with Moebius syndrome have dysarthria that can be mild to profound in severity depending on the extent of oral-motor involvement(1,11) -Bilabial sounds (/b/, /p/, and /m/) and labiodental fricatives (/f/, /v/) are often the most problematic for individuals with Moebius syndrome to produce due to anatomical abnormalities(1) -Assessments of articulationstandardized assessment that quantifies single-word  and sentence-level  intelligibility and speaking rate of dysarthric speakers; normed for individuals aged 12 and older(11)standardized assessment of speech neuromuscular activity, including respiration, articulation, resonance, phonation, and speech-related  reflexes; normed for individuals aged 12 and older(11) -Speech sample of at least 50 utterances to estimate overall percentage of intelligibility, document the nature of specific speech sound errors, and determine rate of speech(11) -For detailed information regarding assessment of articulation skills in individuals with Moebius syndrome, see  ClinicalArticulation Disorder, Organic ; Topic ID Number Clinical Reviews on dysarthriaAssess receptive and expressive language skills as indicated. Moebius syndrome itself does not cause problems in language acquisition and developmentAssess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance.(11) If there are specific concerns regarding voice, refer to otolaryngologist for complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies prior to completing a full
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document the presence of any cognitive or intellectual disability –Individuals with Moebius syndrome have a slightly increased risk of intellectual disability; however, most patients with Moebius syndrome have normal intelligence(3)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls due to lack of lateral eye movement and poor peripheral vision.  (1) Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
It is important to consider an individual and family’s cultural and/or linguistic background during the development of therapy activities

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Most patients with Moebius syndrome will be appropriate for speech therapy intervention to target speech and feeding/swallowing problems that result from the disorder
assessment plan of care.rule out: Prior to diagnosing Moebius syndrome, the patient’s medical team will rule out other possible causes of symptoms, including myasthenia gravis, cerebral palsy, and Down syndrome
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physical therapist for gait training, strengthening exercises, and lower limb involvement(1,2) Occupational therapist for ADLs, feeding issues, fine motor skills, and upper limb involvement(1) Surgeon/plastic surgeon for surgical interventions for Moebius syndrome(1) Counseling, social services, or other mental health professional for the varied psychosocial needs of an individual with Moebius syndrome and his or her family(1) Ophthalmologist for problems related to vision, eye movement, and eye health(1) Dentist and/or orthodontist for issues related to dentition and occlusion(1,12)
other considerations: It is important that persons who will regularly interact with the patient (e.g., teachers, neighbors, extended family members) are educated about Moebius syndrome and the specific needs of the patient(1)

Children with Moebius syndrome are often teased and excluded by other children for their appearance as well as their inability to participate in childhood activities such as blowing bubbles, inflating a balloon, or blowing out birthday candles(1)
treatment summary: Articulation/dysarthria therapy –Labial strengthening exercises(11) –Velopharyngeal therapy(11) -For detailed information on therapy for velopharyngeal dysfunction, see Clinical Review…Velopharyngeal Dysfunction ; Topic ID Number:T708864 –For detailed information on treatment of articulation/dysarthria in individuals with Moebius syndrome, see Clinical Review…Speech Sound Disorders: Articulation Disorder, Organic , referenced above, and the series of Clinical Reviews on dysarthria

Functional communication strategies –Approximate difficult sounds using alternative articulatory placement(1) –Substitute a word that is not understood with a synonym that does not contain the problem sound (e.g., saying “large” instead of “big”)(1) –Augment verbal output with gestures or body language(1,13) –Press a finger to the lip to achieve labial sounds(1) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Reduced intelligibility of speechIncreased speech intelligibility; functional communicationArticulation/ dysarthria therapy _ See Treatment summary , above for details _ _ Functional training _ Functional communication strategies(1) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveProgression of therapeutic tasks depends on specific goals as well as the level and degree of impairment of each individual patientThe SLP will provide the patient’s family members and/or teacher with information for home practice activities Dysphagia; feeding disorderImprove the safety, adequacy, and/ or efficiency of swallowing and feedingDysphagia therapy _ See the series of Clinical Reviews on dysphagia and dysphagia therapyProgression of therapeutic tasks depends on specific goals as well as the level and degree of impairment of each individual patientThe SLP will provide the patient’s family members and/or teacher with information on appropriate foods, liquids, and compensatory strategies for swallowing and feeding safety as appropriate .

improved speech intelligibility: Assessment of Intelligibility of Dysarthric Speech
review of the goals set in the initial p: For children with Moebius syndrome, outcome statements outlined in the IFSP or IEP should indicate the context orenvironment in which the outcomes should occur

maintenance or prevention: Because Moebius syndrome is rare, healthcare professionals are not always familiar with the signs and symptoms, and diagnosis may be delayed until adolescence or adulthood; providing education to nurses and physicians who work in prenatal, perinatal, pediatric, neonatal, or midwifery specialties will help these professionals recognize Moebius syndrome in babies and children, allowing for definitive diagnosis and early support and/or surgical treatment(1)
patient education: Find resources for patients, family members, and professionals, as well as information about support groups, at the Moebius Syndrome Foundation website, https://moebiussyndrome.org/  Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on March 3, 2017 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
